content.body: I do not have a strong opinion. My weak opinion teeters. Just facts: TextEncoder had to be static because the byte array could not be the receiver. The “into” term indicates that writer array is an argument, not a return or the receiver. By contrast “copyWithin” implies both the reader and writer are the receiver. I don’t know a modifier word precedent for indicating the operation writes to the receiver and reads from an argument.
content.formatted_body: I do not have a strong opinion. My weak opinion teeters. Just facts: TextEncoder had to be static because the byte array could not be the receiver. The “into” term indicates that writer array is an argument, not a return or the receiver. By contrast “copyWithin” implies both the reader and writer are the receiver. I don’t know a modifier word precedent for indicating the operation writes to the receiver and reads from an argument.

content.body: So nothing prevents the method from being on the prototype but it is easier to name on the constructor.
content.formatted_body: So nothing prevents the method from being on the prototype but it is easier to name on the constructor.

content.body:
> I don’t know a modifier word precedent for indicating the operation writes to the receiver and reads from an argument.

Plausibly [`fill`](https://tc39.es/ecma262/multipage/indexed-collections.html#sec-%typedarray%.prototype.fill), which I guess for this proposal would suggest something like `Uint8Array.prototype.fillFromBase64`
content.formatted_body:
I don’t know a modifier word precedent for indicating the operation writes to the receiver and reads from an argument.

Plausibly fill, which I guess for this proposal would suggest something like Uint8Array.prototype.fillFromBase64

content.body: Maybe `set`? `DataView.prototype.setUint32()` sets multiple bytes on the receiver from an argument.
content.formatted_body: Maybe set? DataView.prototype.setUint32() sets multiple bytes on the receiver from an argument.

content.body: `fill` usually means performing a repetitive action, like "fill this array with zeroes"
content.formatted_body: fill usually means performing a repetitive action, like "fill this array with zeroes"

content.body: yep, `set` appears to be the other prior instance of that pattern
content.formatted_body: yep, set appears to be the other prior instance of that pattern

content.body: This is also a somewhat new capability in the standard library, so something precedent-setting isn't necessarily uncalled for. I would generally use a term like `write` for this kind of operation elsewhere.
content.formatted_body: This is also a somewhat new capability in the standard library, so something precedent-setting isn't necessarily uncalled for. I would generally use a term like write for this kind of operation elsewhere.
